Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Story: I stepped into the lobby, umbrella dripping, and spotted Mrs. Kim from 402. She smiled, but her eyes darted to the building manager, who was holding a clipboard. The noise complaint had everyone on edge. As a neighbor, I was expected to be friendly, polite, maybe even offer a reassuring word. I forced a smile, nodding to everyone, trying to seem approachable. But my phone buzzed—my next taxi shift was about to start, and the rain outside was relentless. I knew the roads would be slick, other drivers impatient, and as a taxi driver, I was expected to follow every traffic law, drive defensively, and keep my passengers safe. My mind raced: should I linger and be the good neighbor, smoothing over tensions, or rush out to meet my shift, bracing for the stress of the wet roads and unpredictable traffic? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
